page.title: 05TRANSPORT
page.content: A CANAL WAS BUILT AT THE BEGINNING OF THE NINETEENTH CENTURY, MAINLY TO CARRY COAL,IRON AND LIMESTONE TO THE WHARF AT BRITON FERRY. THE CANAL FELL INTO DECLINE SOME SIXTY YEARS LATER WHEN THE VALE OF NEATH RAILWAY WAS OPENED IN 1851. THE RAILWAY WAS IN OPERATION FOR OVER ONE HUNDRED YEARS BUT IN 1962 IT WAS CLOSED BECAUSE IT WAS FOUND TO BE UNECONOMIC.AS A RESULT OF THE CLOSURE, ROAD TRAFFIC TO AND FROM THE WEST MIDLANDS HAS INCREASED CONSIDERABLY. A BY-PASS WAS OPENED AT GLYNNEATH IN 1978 BUT A PROPOSED DUAL CARRIAGEWAY LINKING GLYNNEATH TO ABERDULAIS EIGHT MILES AWAY HAS YET TO BE BUILT. {NO. OF VEHICLES TRAVELLING ON A465 {BETWEEN 1100 AND 1200:- {CARS}463 {LORRIES}114 {VANS}77 {AVERAGE NO. OF VEHICLES PER HOUR}662
